section.title: Spot Rates and Forward Rates
section.p: In , we will meet spot rates and forward rates. A spot rate is an effective annual interest rate offered today (time 0) for investment for a period of time. For example, the spot rate s_0(1) is the annual rate offered now for a 1-year investment, and s_0(2) is the annual rate offered now for a 2-year investment. A forward rate is a 1-year rate over a period that is implied by spot rates. So given s_0(1) and s_0(2), there is an implied forward rate \iota_0(1,2) for the time between Years 1 and 2. There zeros in the subscripts just indicate that we are thinking of investments made today. Let us take a look at how this works!

introduction.p: Suppose we have spot rates s_0(1) = 2\% for a 1-year investment today and s_0(2) = 3.5\% for a 2-year investment today.

task.p: Generate an interest rate timeline. Remember that s_0(1) is in effect between years 0 and 1, s_0(2) is a 1-year rate but in effect between years 0 and 2, and \iota_0(1,2) is a rate that is expected to be in effect between years 1 and 2.

In order for the market to work (based on the no-arbitrage rule), the two options above must yield the same value at the end of the 2-year period. Use this to set up and solve an equation for \iota_0(1,2).
